question: Where were you born and what was your early life like?
answer: I was born in Fort Knox, Kentucky, and I'm an army brat, so I'm from all over.
source_text: I was born in Kentucky Fort Knox Kentucky and Im an army brat so Im from all over

question: What challenges did your parents face when looking for housing in San Francisco?
answer: When my parents first went looking for housing, they were told that Green and Kaufman didn't sell to black people in the Richmond, even if they had the money.
source_text: when my parents first went looking for housing in the city um they went to green and Kaufman on yerry street and they were told that they didnt not that green and Kaufman I dont I dont think it was the statement that green and Kaufman didnt sell to black people but theyre saying that if you want to buy in the Richmond they didnt sell to black people

question: How did the development and city planning affect lower Pacific Heights and the Fillmore district?
answer: Developers eliminated lower Pacific Heights, which was a black area, and drove prices up. The Fillmore district was dug up and left empty for years, scattering the community.
source_text: lower Pacific ice was all black it was a black area until developers came in and scores people out and drove the prices everything up you know development in the city planners eliminated lower Pacific Heights they dug up the Fillmore district and left it empty for eight and ten years

question: How does Angelo Wilson describe the treatment of poor people in the city?
answer: There's no attention to those folks; they don't care about poor people. It's a non-profit racket, a billion dollars a year to scrape crap off the street.
source_text: all the south of Market flop houses are gone you got people living on the street being on the sidewalks theres no attention to those folks they dont care about poor people it it its a non-profit racket a billion dollars a year to scrape crap off the street

question: What does Angelo Wilson recall about his mother's reaction to the Presidio when they first arrived in San Francisco?
answer: My mother looked around the Presidio and said, 'Oh, this is nice, this is much too nice for poor people.'
source_text: Ill tell you the story about my mother when she got out of the car when we just we had just came from France in 64 and she out of the car looked around the Presidio thats where we were going to live the first three years here thats where I lived she looked around and said oh this is nice this is much too nice for poor people

question: What does Angelo Wilson say about the historical integration efforts in San Francisco schools?
answer: He describes how integration was superficial, with black and white students being separated in practice despite being in the same school. He recalls being on the white side of the playground as an Army brat, while black students were on the other side.
source_text: when I went to Winfield Scott as a army brat they were integrating San Francisco back in early 60s and they would ship in kids from the Fillmore to Winfield Scott Winfield Scott is now clearly lillianthal in the Marina District when they shipped when they talked about um what do you call integration they would ship to people from The Fillmore in to Winfield Scott but they would they would go to separate classes youd have one side of the playground all black the other side because I was an Army rat I was in the white side of the playground so they had integration but they didnt integrate on on the books it was supposedly happening but they separated the kids
